note.body:
Yup, I used a virtualenv to test 3.32.1. It's odd that you're getting a UnicodeDecodeError exception as my test script is supposed to catch them. You still didn't get as far as calling get_tag_multiple a second time though. Here's what I'm currently getting with 3.26.1:

```
jim@brains:~$ python3 non_utf8_test.py 
PyGObject version 3.26.1

** (process:640): CRITICAL **: Directory Canon with 6144 entries considered invalid; not read.
get_tag_string
'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xe9 in position 23: invalid continuation byte
get_tag_string
'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xe9 in position 23: invalid continuation byte
get_tag_multiple
'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xe9 in position 4: invalid continuation byte
get_tag_multiple
*** Error in `python3': double free or corruption (out): 0x000055d787f3c6c0 ***
Aborted (core dumped)
```

events.target_title: Segfault when returning a list of strings that have non utf8 characters.

note.body:
I think I might have found the problem, but I'm not sufficiently familiar with the PyGObject sources to be sure.

In pygi-array.c the function `_pygi_marshal_to_py_array` calls `item_to_py_marshaller` for each string in the list. When the UTF-8 decoding fails this function returns NULL. When this happens `g_array_unref (array_)` is called before jumping to the `err` label where `g_array_free` is called on the same array. This looks odd to me, and removing the `g_array_unref` call does stop the crash.

events.target_title: Allow floating point value for webview body font size

note.body:
Ok, I will try check coding styles and other places starting from tomorrow. I’m not familiar with evolution codebase.


Concerning the WebKitSettings::default-font-size, I think this is a different issue. Those settings are used to set in pixel (not point, so much unlikely using float values) the default browser font size. 

Moreover, except for very special cases, the webkit default should be left untouched. The default values (16px for default font and 13px for monospace) are web standards used as a basis to compute “em” font size value (16px == 1em).
https://webkitgtk.org/reference/webkit2gtk/stable/WebKitSettings.html#WebKitSettings--default-font-size

I  see that this webkit default font sizes are set to the UI font settings converted in pixel. This seems to me a mistake and should remain to the default values without configuration setting, or a separate setting like the one you can see in a web browser. Even with HiDPI screens, I do not think that altering these defaults is a need, as gtk is handling the scaling globally if I’m not mistaken.

What is your though on this point?

But it’s up to you of course.

Hope the coding style is better for you to.

events.target_title: Allow floating point value for webview body font size

note.body:
For what it worth, if I put your sample message in my roundcube client, I get the same behaviour as the old one: the mail viewer pane has an initial font size of 1rem, but the reference size is forced at the top level (<html> node of the webmail UI) to a value depending on the theme (eg 11px or 14px for the 2 themes I tested).

If I put the mail on my corporate MS Exchange 2016, the OWA hardcode a 15px font size for the initial font size, so it’s nearly the same as the new behaviour (by why 15px and not the standard 16px?), and MS Outlook seems to give me the same behaviour as the new one (but I not sure in this case, MS Outlook mises tools to precisely check the rendered HTML css)

I have no other clients installed at the moment to compare the behavior.
So… Personally I think I prefer the new behavior, but it’s up to you.

The first part of the patch dealing with the fractional font size is much more important to me as it impacts the font size homogeneity across the evolution interface.

Cheese only uses video/x-raw formats, and not image/jpeg
Cheese only uses video/x-raw formats, and not image/jpeg

note.body:
I am also not familar with gstreamer, but am slowly trying to pick it up.

The function `cheese_camera_set_video_recording()` is building part of the pipeline responsible for recording video from the camera. It is building a pipeline that can produce:

- a webm container with
  - video encoded with vp8
  - audio encoded with ogg

I think the call in `cheese_camera_set_video_recording()`, on `cheese-camera.c:491`, sets the format of the recorded file:

```
  g_object_set (priv->camerabin, "video-profile", prof, NULL);
```

The **source** for that pipeline is also a property of `priv->camerabin`, but it's setup in `cheese_camera_set_camera_source()`, on `cheese-camera.c:396`:

```
  src = cheese_camera_device_get_src (selected_camera);
  gst_bin_add (GST_BIN (priv->video_source), src);
```

`selected_camera` is of type `CheeseCameraDevice`. In that class, there are two hardcoded references to `video/x-raw` that you've already found.

My hunch is that the first place something has to change in Cheese is in `CheeseCameraDevice` so that when `cheese_camera_device_get_src` returns an object, that object is already configured to provide a (in your case) `video/x-h264` source.

events.target_title: Crash when using with Sourcetree DIFF in 3.20: Cannot import gi / Cannot import GTK+: The specific module could not be found

note.body:
I think I saw the same issue in a different context (using diff from the GitExtensions tool). What works for me was **unsetting the `MSYSTEM` environment variable**, through a wrapper batch file.

In `git version 2.20.1.windows.1` git adds this variable to the environment of the child diff tool process it starts, with value `MINGW64`. Meld seems to get confused by this.

MeldDiffTool.bat:
```bash
setlocal
set MSYSTEM=
call "C:\Program Files (x86)\Meld\Meld.exe" %1 %2
endlocal
```

And the corresponding git config:
```ini
[diff]
	guitool = meld
[difftool "meld"]
	path = \"C:/Program Files (x86)/Meld\"
	cmd = \"C:/some_path/MeldDiffTool.bat\" \"$LOCAL\" \"$REMOTE\"
```

You can apply a similar workaround to the mergetool.

note.body:
Sorry David,
I am lost as to why there are references to unknow or reserved fields in the Response. There are no unknown or reserved fields in MS-NLMP for any of the various messages.
Also I noteice that NTLMString is handled incorrectly as the offset is encoded as a 16 bit LE integer, but in the docs offsets are always 32bit LE integers. It only works because in LE a 16 bit integer does end up encoding for the lower 16bit of the 32bit integer as well ...

I would suggest the authors to seriously consider using gssntlmssp and throw away the burden of trying to support NTLM by themselves.

Or at least look at that implementation to understand what they need to do to support features. It is a complete implementation of the NTLM spec.

events.target_title: Add a gnutls backend for GHmac

note.body:
@walters thank you this looks promising, do you want me to open a GnuTLS bug to implement an hmac copy for completeness?

@pwithnall FIPS certification is done against specific binaries only, not on source code, so you cannot simply embed some code, you'd still have to dynamically lienk or dlopen() an external library (technically you can also statically link to a static library build that has been validated I think, but that is more complicated).

events.target_title: Add a gnutls backend for GHmac

note.body: @mcatanzaro would an openssl backend help with the licensing issue ?

events.target_title: Add a gnutls backend for GHmac

note.body:
Optionally linking to GnuTLS via build time configure option is the simplest short term.

In the long term dlopening libgio may also be ok, given it is very likely that any application playing with an hmac is doing that because it is using it for some network authentication scheme, so it is almost certainly already linking to libgio.

The only thing I would like to avoid though is a library that has different behavior in FIPS mode vs non-FIPS mode on the same system. It creates potential issues for regressions in the last used mode.

Also in RHEL/Fedora we introduced the crypto-policies stuff, which is about controlling what crypto algorithms admins want to allow regardless of FIPS mode. Given MD5/SHA1 are all things an admin may want to control, having GHmac always go through a crypto library gives us better chances of controlling that for all applications.

events.target_title: Add a gnutls backend for GHmac

note.body: I would rather give distributions a choice of libraries if you are going to allow linking one.

note.body: @walters sorry, i turned out I was logged out and didn't notice, I logged in and turned off confidentiality for the issue, and now it should be visibile to anyone.

events.target_title: Add a gnutls backend for GHmac

note.body: @mcatanzaro although NSS does not explicitly warn against use in libraries, past experience (from the old crypto consolidation project Red Hat attempted) made us learn that NSS is a poor fit to be used from libraries as well. It can be made to work, but it is hard (tends to use global contexts and complicated initialization which is a poor fit if linked from multiple libraries or a program and, independently, its dependencies), it was developed to be used as a direct dependency of a binary (Firefox and other Netscape products back then) and it shows. If you have a choice I would look at GnuTLS and OpenSSL before laying your eyes on NSS.

events.target_title: Add a gnutls backend for GHmac

note.body: Btw, libkcapi might be an option, I guess, if you are ok with Linux sepcific dependencies, and with slow APIs (due to context switches).

The TPM2 interface does offer HMAC, as well as the PKCS11 interface, so using a crypto library would indeed allow to gain HSM support for this functionality.

Looks like I can reproduce 100% CPU each time on switching to box with a lot of mails. Sometimes - it possible without switching, just right once after start. But about 100% chance to catch it via switch to "all mails" (~20k mails total).

Feature Request: Have a way to open PDFs in an external reader

note.body: I back this up. A classic "Open with..." entry in the top right burger menu would allow one to use e.g. Evince to comfortably read a document. Also clicking on hyperlinks and scrolling with trackpad do not work (for me?) within Paperwork, but I do not consider this an issue that much, since that is out-of-scope for the project IMO. Paperwork is a document indexer, tagger and search engine, it is not meant to read documents, even though a basic viewer is implemented for convenience.

events.target_title: Error loading TIF file with JPEG compression

note.body:
![Screenshot_20190528_200256](/uploads/06cb0faf8d8a4914b260ee7a18afab7d/Screenshot_20190528_200256.png)

I tested on 2 different PC's. Both with Ubuntu 18.04. Identical errors.

events.target_title: Error loading TIF file with JPEG compression

note.body:
$ tiffinfo test.tif 
```
TIFF Directory at offset 0x81ae (33198)
  Subfile Type: (0 = 0x0)
  Image Width: 640 Image Length: 480
  Resolution: 72, 72 pixels/inch
  Bits/Sample: 8
  Compression Scheme: JPEG
  Photometric Interpretation: RGB color
  Orientation: row 0 top, col 0 lhs
  Samples/Pixel: 3
  Rows/Strip: 64
  Planar Configuration: single image plane
  DocumentName: /home/dkrav/Изображения/test.tif
  ImageDescription: Created with GIMP
  JPEG Tables: (289 bytes)
```

`tiffcp -c none test.tif test2.tif `
This produces tif file without compression. And GIMP opens this file.

events.target_title: Error loading TIF file with JPEG compression

note.body: Installed a snap package of GIMP 2.10.10 stable. The problems disappeared. Apparently the problem in flatpack dependencies/

events.target_title: Crash when using with Sourcetree DIFF in 3.20: Cannot import gi / Cannot import GTK+: The specific module could not be found

note.body:
I can also confirm that the workaround with adding the lib folder to the path does the trick. Fixes it for powershell, git-bash and GitExtensions.

What's quite interesting is that the mergetool call did work nevertheless. It was just the diff which crashed.

events.target_title: tracker-extract causes system lock-up due to 100% CPU and memory usage

note.body:
I am also having this issue.

note.body:
Well, there are some limitations there:
*  I'm already oversubscribed right now
*  I'm rusty in C
*  I know nothing about GIMP internals (my comment in the bug description comes from just a brief glance at app/core/gimpimage-convert-indexed.c)
*  Implementing a high-quality, performant quantizer in GIMP would be non-trivial (libimagequant is several thousand lines of code)

But libimagequant is GPLv3, used by a number of other projects beyond pngquant2, and is actively maintained. Maybe it's best to just use it?

events.target_title: gnome-software using 59% of memory

note.body:
I have also been experiencing severe Gnome Software memory leaks. In my case, the problem seems to present itself every other weeks or so. When it happens, Gnome Software's memory usages starts increasing with several hundreds of megabytes per second, which I sometimes noticed in time by the slightly decreased responsiveness of my system so that I was able to kill the process in time. I've witnessed it taking well over 10 GB of RAM in such cases. When not noticed in time, it would fill up the free memory and start swapping to my SSD, at which point the system becomes totally unresponsive to all input, resulting in me having to hard reset the system. As one can imagine, that's quite annoying when at work. 

I'm a suspend-resume kind of guy, and reboot something like once or twice a week, and I don't recall having experienced the problem soon after a clean boot, though that may be a coincidence. 

I have experienced the issue on up-to-date Fedora 29 (so with Gnome Software version 3.30), but have upgraded to Fedora 30 (Gnome 3.32) a week ago after disabling two repositories, after which I have yet to experience the issue again, but that may be a coincidence as well.

A couple of weeks ago (so still on Fedora 29), the issue did present itself while running via Valgrind as instructed at https://wiki.gnome.org/Valgrind. The memcheck-amd64- process occupied 6.8 GB when it ran out of RAM. I have the Valgrind output log and a 708 MB coredump file. I attached the last 5000 lines of the log file. [vgdump_tail](/uploads/e0f4c79b62cdda57ffe65f44028a2b80/vgdump_tail)

If any developer would like any more information, be sure to let me know.

As a side note, what is a typical amount of memory for Gnome Software to use? Just today, after a fresh boot, opening Software and checking for updates, it's using 340MB, which strikes me as a bit much.

events.target_title: gnome-software using 59% of memory

note.body: I have yet to experience the humongous memory leak again after upgrading to both Fedora 30 and 31, i.e. with Gnome Software 3.32 and 3.34.

The keyboard shortcuts still seem to be broken. In addition, the workaround suggested above does nothing for me.

```
$ XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP=XFCE simple-scan
```

brings up exactly the same new UI as does a value of `GNOME`, or leaving it at the default (`i3`).

I'm on simple-scan version `3.32.2.1`, using an up-to-date Arch Linux with i3 window manager.

events.target_title: Preferences Color Management Policies
Preferences Color Management Policies - Better text when opening files with embedded ICC profiles

note.body:
@ellestone Thanks for your reply. The Image Properties Color Profile of a scan opened for the first time in GIMP are: 

GIMP built-in sRGB
sRGB
Manufacturer: GIMP
Copyright: Public Domain

The recommended color settings in the scanner's software is sRGB IEC61966-2.1, which does not appear to be the same as the GIMP profile. 

How can I ascertain whether a scanned TIFF has an embedded ICC profile without opening it with GIMP?

events.target_title: Preferences Color Management Policies - Better text when opening files with embedded ICC profiles

note.body:
Thank you for your help with this. I recognize that this is not a support forum. 

Based on the output of exiftool when a TIFF created by my scanning software is input, there does not seem to be an ICCProfile stored in the file. See the attached file.

I suppose this means GIMP is operating correctly and @DerAndere and I are looking for an enhancement; however, the documentation and instructions for the preference setting that led to this discussion should clearly state that "ask what to do" and "assign preferred profile" do not apply to images which lack a stored profile. This might have saved us all the time spent discussing the GIMP "feature."
[IMG_20190607_0016.txt](/uploads/cfa200c82c6920b7f3221f51480d769f/IMG_20190607_0016.txt)

note.body:
How about this tooltip language: "How to handle opening files with embedded color profiles" ? This language seems more specific to me. 

FWIW, just now I opened an image with an embedded profile. My preference is set to "Ask what to do." The choices presented were to keep the embedded (Nikon) profile or convert to the GIMP built-in sRGB profile. My preferred profile is ProPhoto RGB, but it's not an option from the menu. Guess this is an enhancement, so I'll mention it elsewhere. Thanks!

push_data.commit_title: Fix shlibs ldd call on Windows

events.target_title: Fix shlibs ldd call on Windows
Fix shlibs ldd call on Windows

note.body:
I'm using MSYS 1.0, but I suppose the issue is the same on cygwin as both shells would call ldd with the same arguments.
Moreover, my ldd version is the one coming with cygwin: ldd (cygwin) 2.11.2.

In fact the issue may come from ldd which cannot solve correctly paths relative to the argument if input path contains anti-slashes.
I mean 'ldd Z:\\folder\\prog.exe' fails whereas 'ldd Z:/folder/prog.exe' works.

The invalid path is provided by the Cerbero build system used to build gstreamer suite.
I've added a patch in Cerbero to bypass the issue but I think it may be useful for you too :smile: 
or not...

events.target_title: Fix shlibs ldd call on Windows

note.body:
If it's working well with msys2, you're right it should not be included.

I'm closing the request.

Thanks a lot for your time reviewing it :+1: :smile:

well it sounds tiny issue for you maybe but since physical keyboard doesnt have any led light indicator for Caps lock on some laptop brands (Lenovo ThinkPad x230 doesnt have for example), it is annoying.

events.target_title: 100% CPU hogging if FritzBox 7240 / D-Link DIR-635 is present in the network

note.body:
I have done some more investigation using a small test program (see also the issue on GitHub linked from previous comment). When calling `gupnp_service_proxy_set_subscribed()` (file `libgupnp/gupnp-service-proxy.c`) from my client code with `subscribed` set to `TRUE`, function `subscribe()` gets called, which calls `soup_session_queue_message()` in turn and sets `subscribe_got_response()` as callback. On success, that function is supposed to set the subscription ID (`proxy->priv->sid`). While waiting for the message completion, `emit_notifications()` is repeatedly called (callback for an idle source constructed in `server_handler()`). First thing this function does is checking the `proxy->priv->sid` pointer, and returning `TRUE` if it is still `NULL`. Now, for the problematic FRITZ!Box 7240, the `subscribe_got_response()` callback is called only after 1 minute. In the meantime, we have a busy loop which causes 100% CPU load. The message status is `SOUP_STATUS_IO_ERROR` in this case: 
>>> print *msg
$1 = {
  parent = {
    g_type_instance = {
      g_class = 0x555555793500
    },
    ref_count = 1,
    qdata = 0x0
  },
  method = 0x55555577c254 "SUBSCRIBE",
  status_code = 7,
  reason_phrase = 0x555555d60ff0 "Connection terminated unexpectedly",
  request_body = 0x555555d3b300,
  request_headers = 0x555555d3b400,
  response_body = 0x555555d3b480,
  response_headers = 0x555555b5da40
After that, the CPU load from my small test program goes down again. I have tested with the current gupnp-1.0 branch (all other libraries used as shipped with Ubuntu 18.04.2), but I suspect that the problem persists in master as well since the code looks quite similar. Maybe it would be possible to have a rate limit on `emit_notifications()` or some explicit synchronization to avoid the high CPU load while waiting for the subscription ID ?

events.target_title: CalDAV-advertised WebCal is not imported
CalDAV-advertised WebCal is not imported

note.body:
Webcal is already supported. CalDAV is supported as well. I was able to import both separately.

I am by no means an expert on CalDAV, but I did some research into the implementation Nextcloud uses.

It seems that although it is not in the official standard, Apple has made an extension to CalDAV. 

Nextcloud / ownCloud has adopted this standard.
DAVdroid / ICSdroid (recently rebranded to DAVx5) supports it as well.

In Nextcloud I can subscribe, using the calendar app, to certain read-only webcal feeds. For example for university timetables.
These get automatically pushed to all the devices logged on to this account. The colour set for these calendars is also synchronised.

As far as I understand now, only the link to the feed and the colour is synced, not the calendar data itself, which is retrieved directly from the webcal source.

These are parts of the research that I did that I think are most relevant:

<https://github.com/nextcloud/server/issues/1497>

"Technically, WebCal calendars are already exposed via CalDAV as a special collection type called subscription. But that's not part of the CalDAV standard. Therefore it's only supported by a limited variety of Calendar applications like iOS, macOS and apparently certain Android apps."

<https://github.com/nextcloud/calendar/issues/63>

Example of the way Nextcloud pushes webcal feeds:

```xml
<d:response>
    <d:href>/nextcloud/remote.php/dav/calendars/test/my-subscription/</d:href>
    <d:propstat>
        <d:prop>
        <d:resourcetype>
            <d:collection/>
            <cs:subscribed/>
        </d:resourcetype>
```

events.target_title: GIMP freezes when 'Invert' is clicked from the 'selection' drop down menu
Fails to copy screen area to clipboard under i3 (X11)

note.body:
I was having similar issues in dwm and can confirm that this has nothing to do with i3.

The problem here is in relation to how the X server handles clipboard _selections_.

One typically think of copy-paste as whatever you copy is copied into the clipboard memory so that you can paste it later.

With X clipboard selections how this works is that you select something in one window and when you copy you are actually just copying the selection reference into the clipboard. Only when you paste the data is retrieved from the original window. While this saves on resources (memory), you can't paste after the application has closed as the data is no longer there.

When running `gnome-screenshot --area --clipboard` on the command line the selection reference is indeed copied into the clipboard, but the application exits after that so the captured image is immediately lost.

The same is true if you open the interactive GUI, grab the area, then click the copy into clipboard button. You'd find that you can now paste the image just fine, but if you close the application then you can no longer paste.

The primary clipboard behaves more like one would expect in that data is copied directly into the clipboard and remains there even if the source application closes.

I think the fix could be as simple as changing `GDK_SELECTION_CLIPBOARD` into `GDK_SELECTION_PRIMARY` here:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-screenshot/blob/master/src/screenshot-application.c#L400

Alternatively ensure that the data is copied into the primary clipboard only when the tool is being run using the `--clipboard` command-line option.

For those looking for a quick fix I worked around this by using some imagemagick tools instead:
```bash
import - | convert - png:- | xclip -selection clipboard -target image/png -i
```

events.target_title: Fails to copy screen area to clipboard under i3 (X11)

note.body:
For what it is worth running `gnome-screenshot -a -c` under gnome does seem to work.

In other window managers if I am running a clipboard manager like `clipit` or `copyq`, then run `gnome-screenshot -i`, select an area to grab, and then click on the "Copy to Clipboard" button the image is indeed copied into the clipboard manager. This (of course) remains after closing gnome-screenshot.

Running `gnome-screenshot -a -c` on the command line, however, does not actually result in the screenshot being copied into the clipboard manager's memory because gnome-screenshot exits before this can happen. I can only see this being worked around with an option to delay exiting with a second or so to allow the clipboard manager time enough to copy the selection data, but I can understand if introducing such an option is not desirable.

events.target_title: Fails to copy screen area to clipboard under i3 (X11)

note.body:
It may be that it is due to falling back to X11 in this case.
```
$ gnome-screenshot -a -c
** Message: 17:32:11.065: Unable to select area using GNOME Shell's builtin screenshot interface, resorting to fallback X11.
** Message: 17:32:12.995: Unable to use GNOME Shell's builtin screenshot interface, resorting to fallback X11.
```

> How did you conclude that this is a timing issue? Or was it just the best guess for what was happening?

It is a best guess. If I run the interactive mode and I close gnome-screenshot manually shortly after clicking the "Copy to Clipboard" button the screenshot is also not captured by the clipboard manager.

The other reason is that if I run `clipit` I see this error shortly after gnome-screenshot has exited.

```
$ clipit
Clipboard is null, recovering ...
```

I don't see anything like this in `copyq`, however, even with debug logging enabled so not 100% sure.

push_data.commit_title: Fix leading zeros in bitwise operation

events.target_title: Fix leading zeros in bitwise operation
Fix leading zeros in bitwise operation

note.body:
Thank you for your prompt answer and your fix @robertroth. 

First of all, `parse_literal_prefix` seems to work as intended (even before you removed the `0`-prefixing functionality for octal bases). The function parses the prefix and determines the base. `0`-prefixing is confusing to use and it's good that it is removed.

However, I don't think your changes fix the root cause of the underlying problem. Guessing the numeral base should not be done if it can be specified explicitly. After bitwise operations we _know_ that we are working with hexadecimal bases. This should be passed to the `mp_set_from_string` function.

I tried to change the signature of the `mp_set_from_string` to accept an optional explicit base without much success (i don't know how it is intended to be used and how Vala works). The Workaround to remove the leading zeros after the bitwise operation seemed to be a minimal invasive solution.

As a result of the _guesswork_, there could be errors in other parts of the calculator. As @mst showed me today, one example is:

1.  Set calculator to 16bit mode
2.  Set calculator to hexadecimal mode
3.  Type: `¬F400`
4.  Press enter

Expected: `BFF`

Actual: `Malformed Expression`

Cause: `F400` is inverted to `0BFF`, which is interpreted as a binary number by `parse_literal_prefix`, leading to `F` being an illegal token in a binary expression.

I can open a separate issue for this if you like. I also cannot estimate the amount of changes that would be required for passing an explicit base. Also, some tests to prevent regression of this issue would not hurt :wink: .

Thank you for your time.

events.target_title: NTFS Resize results in Partition Information Warning on Refresh

note.body:
> Volume is scheduled for check.
> Please boot into Windows TWICE, or use the 'force' option.
> NOTE: If you had not scheduled check and last time accessed this volume,...
> etc.

ntfsresize marks the resized partition to be checked upon the first mount on Windows, and it has been so for twenty odd years.

This does not prevent the partition from mounting with ntfs-3g.

To remove the dirty flag, you may run "ntfsfix -d /dev/...", and this will tell why the partition cannot be mounted.

events.target_title: NTFS Resize results in Partition Information Warning on Refresh

note.body:
AFAIK the --force on ntfsinfo only enables retrying mounting in read-only mode when the designated device is found read-only (set by a hardware switch). In your situation it is probably not useful.

Note : ntfsinfo does no consistency check of the partition, it just prints the metadata. Probably not what you want.

** edit ** the --force on ntfsinfo also enables displaying metadata on a partition whose metadata has a partial copy held in Windows cache (Windows 10 not fully unmounted). This is a dangerous situation for resizing (which ntfsresize checks).

events.target_title: NTFS Resize results in Partition Information Warning on Refresh

I checked again and made a try. I see that ntfsresize accepts a partition which has not been fully unmounted, but it destroys the reference in the log file so that Windows is forced to refresh its metadata cache.

So after the resizing, the cache condition does not exist any more.

Now, what is the purpose of doing ntfsinfo after the resizing ?

events.target_title: Improving Face Recognition
Face regognition can cause oddly named faces to appear

note.body: Just curious: how does one use an already identified face "to train that face to the recognition algorithm"? Is that in Shotwell Unstable yet (or is it still in Nightly)?

events.target_title: Allow moving the clock from the center

note.body:
>It is true that some users clearly prefer the "traditional" position (there are extensions for it, and non-default sessions like GNOME Classic also move the clock). But that doesn't necessarily mean that those options aren't enough.

>I definitively want stronger arguments before considering it. not least because it's not an easy addition:

Was the move from the right to the centre discussed somewhere concluding with evidence that the change would be an overall improvement (since you are asking for evidence here to the contrary)? For me, it's not just a preference, but an accessibility issue. With a vision impairment, having a defined boundary makes finding things vastly easier for me (this would be a ocular equivalent of Fitts' Law).

events.target_title: Nautilus does not respect "Do nothing" for photos setting for removable media
NetworkManager openconnect fails to connect with immediate failure
Compare date with today using localtime(), instead of UTC
Files should respect the system setting "Never prompt" for drive containing DCIM photos

note.body:
Note as a counterpoint to the position that Files shouldn't follow this preference, that it does respect "Never prompt or start programs on media insertion", which is on the same panel.

Also see https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-control-center/+bug/1830448; it's not just that it prompts, but that it always opens Shotwell.
